Module Information¶

by Christopher Weiss cmweiss@gmail.com and Todd Dembrey todd.dembrey@gmail.com

Adapted from the geomagc software and World Magnetic Model of the NOAA Satellite and Information Service, National Geophysical Data Center http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/geomag/WMM/DoDWMM.shtml

Suggestions for improvements are appreciated.

World Magnetic Model¶

class geomag.WorldMagneticModel(self, world_magnetic_model_filename='WMM.COF')¶

Class for calculating geomagnetic variation according to the world magnetic model

Example Usage:

>>> from geomag import WorldMagneticModel
>>> WorldMagneticModel().calc_mag_field(80,0).declination
-6.1335150785195536

Loads a file containing the constants for the magnetic model.

The coefficients for the model are included for the year 2015 if no variable is provided. File should be in the format of:

degree(n) order(m) g mn(t0) h mn(t0) g mn(t0) h mn(t0)
calc_mag_field(self, dlat, dlon, altitude=0, date=date.today(), unit='ft')¶

Calculates the magnetic field for a given latitude and longditude in decimal degrees.

Parameters

dlat
Latitude in degrees
dlon
Longditude in degrees
altitude : optional
Altitude at which to evaluate magnetic field
date : datetime.date - optional
Time will default to today
unit : {‘ft’,’m’,’km’} - optional
Unit for altitude
field_vectors()¶

Returns the main magentic components: X, Y and Z

mag_heading(hdg)¶

Calculates the magnetic heading from a true heading. hdg = true heading in degrees Example Usage:

>>> wmm.calc_mag_field(0,80).mag_heading(20)
24.0902559647
return_array(*variable_list)¶

Populates a return array with the requested variables, where:

X = Northerly intensity
Y = Easterly intensity
Z = Vertical intensity
H = Horizontal Intensity
F = Total Intensity
I = Inclination
D = Dip
GV = Grid Variation

Example Usage:

>>> wmm.calc_mag_field(0,80).return_array('GV','I')
[355.90974403525763, -23.780099038516493]
